question.title: Why is OpenRewrite not adding an import statement for MoreObjects?
question.body:
I am trying to use OpenRewrite (BOM v 3.14.1) to change all usages of Guava's deprecated Objects#toStringHelper to MoreObjects#toStringHelper.

This is my attempt at the recipe.


    private static final MethodMatcher TO_STRING_HELPER_MATCHER =
            new MethodMatcher("com.google.common.base.Objects toStringHelper(..)");

    public TreeVisitor<?, @NotNull ExecutionContext> getVisitor() {
        return new JavaIsoVisitor<@NotNull ExecutionContext>() {
            @Override
            @NotNull
            public MethodInvocation visitMethodInvocation(@NotNull MethodInvocation method, ExecutionContext ctx) {
                MethodInvocation mi = super.visitMethodInvocation(method, ctx);

                if (TO_STRING_HELPER_MATCHER.matches(mi)) {
                    maybeAddImport("com.google.common.base.MoreObjects");
                    JavaTemplate template = JavaTemplate.builder("MoreObjects.toStringHelper(#{any()})")
                            .build();
                    mi = template.apply(getCursor(), mi.getCoordinates().replace(), mi.getArguments().toArray());
                }

                return mi;
            }
        };

However, in all my tests, the import statement for MoreObjects is not being added. Can anyone explain why?

Moreover, I have one test which gives the following Java as an input:

package foo;

import java.math.BigDecimal;

import com.google.common.base.Function;
import com.google.common.base.Objects;

public class Example {

    private static final Function<Transaction, UnsettledAmount> funcConvertToTransactionUnsettledAmount = new Function<>() {
        @Override
        public UnsettledAmount apply(final Transaction transaction) {
            return new UnsettledAmount() {
                @Override
                public BigDecimal getUnsettledAmount() {
                    return transaction.getUnsettledAmount();
                }

                @Override
                public String toString() {
                    return Objects.toStringHelper(this).add("key", transaction.getId())
                            .add("unsettledAmount", transaction.getUnsettledAmount()).toString();
                }
            };
        }
    };
    
    

    interface Transaction {
        String getId();

        BigDecimal getUnsettledAmount();
    }

    interface UnsettledAmount {
        BigDecimal getUnsettledAmount();

        String toString();
    }
}

and expects the usage of Objects#toStringHelper from the anonymous inner class of UnsettledAmount to be successfully refactored. However, the test keeps on throwing exceptions like

    return new UnsettledAmount() {
        /*~~(MethodDeclaration type is missing or malformed)~~>*/@/*~~(Identifier type is missing or malformed)~~>*/Override
        public BigDecimal getUnsettledAmount() {
            return /*~~(Identifier type is missing or malformed)~~>*/transaction.getUnsettledAmount();
        }

        /*~~(MethodDeclaration type is missing or malformed)~~>*/@/*~~(Identifier type is missing or malformed)~~>*/Override
        public String toString() {
            return /*~~(Identifier type is missing or malformed)~~>*/Objects.toStringHelper(/*~~(Identifier type is missing or malformed)~~>*/this).add("key", /*~~(Identifier type is missing or malformed)~~>*/transaction.getId())
                    .add("unsettledAmount", /*~~(Identifier type is missing or malformed)~~>*/transaction.getUnsettledAmount()).toString();
        }
    };

It's as if anything declared inside the anonymous class, whether a return type, input parameter, or annotation, is not being associated with the imports at the top of the classfile.

answers.body: Your JavaTemplate.builder compiles your code snippet in isolation, and needs to be provided with a Java parser with classpath entry, or .dependsOn with a stub. Once those are added I'd expect this to work.

However, in all my tests, the import statement for MoreObjects is not being added. Can anyone explain why?

I was running into something similar tonight. I would say try using the fully qualified name in the JavaTemplate, so that maybeAddImport() detects the usage correctly. That worked me!

JavaTemplate template = JavaTemplate.builder("com.google.common.base.MoreObjects.toStringHelper(#{any()})")
.build();
